document_title: What is strongyloidiasis? Causes, symptoms and treatment
subsection_content:
1. Clinical
Most strongyloides infections are often asymptomatic and can persist for decades without diagnosis. Symptoms may manifest through the skin, gastrointestinal tract or respiratory tract.; Most strongyloides infections are often asymptomatic and can persist for decades without diagnosis. Symptoms can manifest through the skin, gastrointestinal tract or respiratory tract.
Through the skin: Larvae usually penetrate the legs or any location in contact with infected soil, often causing local dermatitis reactions such as itching and zigzag hives that can change location to suit the allergic reaction. reaction as the larvae migrate, sometimes as a hemorrhagic nodule secondary to ruptured blood vessels. This symptom can last for several hours, all day and recur every month or year.(1); Through the skin: Larvae usually penetrate the legs or any location in contact with infected soil, often causing local dermatitis reactions such as itching and zigzag hives that can change location to suit the allergic reaction. reaction as the larvae migrate, sometimes as a hemorrhagic nodule secondary to ruptured blood vessels. This symptom can last for several hours, all day and recur every month or year. (1)
Gastrointestinal tract: Nausea, vomiting, flatulence, constipation or chronic diarrhea, can even cause intestinal obstruction, sometimes causing malabsorption syndrome. Strongyloidiasis infection is the cause of anorexia, slow growth, and malnutrition in children.; Gastrointestinal tract: Nausea, vomiting, flatulence, constipation or chronic diarrhea, can even cause intestinal obstruction, sometimes causing malabsorption syndrome. Strongyloides infection is the cause of anorexia, slow growth, and malnutrition in children.
Respiratory tract: In mild cases, there will be wheezing and sneezing. When superinfected or superimposed on other diseases, it often causes coughing, wheezing, difficulty breathing, rapid breathing, hemoptysis, pleuritic chest pain, and in severe cases, acute respiratory distress syndrome in adults (ARDS). must be mechanically ventilated.; Respiratory tract: In mild cases, there will be wheezing and sneezing. When superinfected or superimposed on other diseases, it often causes coughing, wheezing, difficulty breathing, rapid breathing, hemoptysis, pleuritic chest pain, and in severe cases, acute respiratory distress syndrome in adults (ARDS). mechanical ventilation is required.
Hyperinfection syndrome: Often occurs in people with exhaustion, immunodeficiency, malignant disease, diabetes, alcoholism. Gr - intestinal bacteria can attach to larvae and move throughout the body, causing blood infections, meningitis, and prolonged fever.; Hyperinfection syndrome: Often occurs in people with exhaustion, immunodeficiency, malignant disease, diabetes, alcoholism. Gr - intestinal bacteria can attach to larvae and move throughout the body, causing blood infections, meningitis, and prolonged fever.
2. Paraclinical
Stool: Stool examination: Worm larvae or eggs may be found (when there is massive diarrhea). Using the Baermann technique to increase sensitivity: Fecal samples to find larvae are incubated in warm water and then centrifuged with liquid agar to detect.; Stool examination: Worm larvae or eggs may be found (when there is massive diarrhea).; Using the Baermann technique to increase sensitivity: Fecal samples to find larvae are incubated in warm water and then centrifuged with liquid agar to detect.; Aspirate duodenal fluid to look for strongyloides larvae; Eosinophil elevation to monitor disease progression and assess the possibility of reinfection.; ELISA tests are highly sensitive and specific, but reliability depends on the laboratory. Antibodies persist many years after successful treatment and can also be (-) pseudo in immunocompromised patients.; Imaging diagnosis: Lung lesions can be infiltrated, nodular, pneumonia or pulmonary edema.
